job_title: Academic Advisor in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: Great team of people, pretty generous PTO, flexible work arrangements.
cons:
Benefits have only been slowly getting worse since I started; deductibles and out-of-pocket maximums went up a total of $1800 for a family in the middle of the year last year. They do not give raises (except when begged for, then it was 1% during the worst inflation period in 4 decades) or pay many of the "front line" folks what they should be paid. Very top heavy when it comes to salaries.
It is an expensive school that does not have all the bells and whistles for students.

job_title: Assistant Manager in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: hard hard hard hard time
cons: i loved how hard the work was

job_title: Admissions Representative in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: None to think of at this time
cons: For such a large private institution they compensate their people poorly when compared to other local institutions

job_title: Admissions in Warren, MI
pros: Good benefits and supportive leadership
cons: Pay is no where near competitive. Not a lot of room for advancement. No annual raises

job_title: Educator in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: You get to work with some really great people who truly care about students and education and bond over horrible management and lack of human decency dished out by executives and HR--People tend to bond over highly stressful situations that force you to cry every because no one knows what you're going through quite like your co-workers. Plus--working at DU makes a great motivator to fill out more applications to get a better job.
cons: Employees are extremely micromanaged, overworked, and underpaid. There have been multiple complaints of harassment, retaliation, and discrimination brought up to HR and it goes unaddressed. It has created an extremely toxic work culture where management believe they can treat lower-level employees however they want and go unpunished--which happens all the time. Turn-over is extremely high because employees are treated poorly and no raises are given and promises of promotions are easily given but never kept. The executive management makes over 200k+, the president makes over 700k+ plus tax-free bonuses and this place has the audacity to freeze the lowest-level employees pay, demote workers, raise health insurance prices, raise tuition, and cut scholarships. It's mind-boggling that it's considered a non-profit. Please save yourself stress, health issues, a lot of tears, and hair loss by not working here. Yikes..

job_title: Campus Assistant in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: Nice people. Some were rude. Pat isn't the best

job_title: Student Accounts Systems Specialist in Grand Rapids, MI
pros:
First, I want to state that the only reason I left DU is because my family was relocating.
-Full-Time staff are given five weeks of PTO when they first start and it only goes up from there.
-Excellent health, dental, and vision benefits.
-DU contributes 10% of your annual wage(s) / salary into a 403b without you needing to contribute a dime.
-My department's staff and leadership were all very kind, fun, and helpful.
-Excellent facilities.
-Supervisors are typically very understanding when family emergencies and issues arise.
cons:
-Executive leadership is very slow and often ineffective.
-Raises are scarce and tiny. The primary way to receive a decent raise is to move up the ladder.
-Because raises are rare and small, wages are fairly low. I felt I was compensated somewhat fairly, but I was only here for a short time. I know many staff members were not paid very well.
-Dealing with students and their guardians can be a drag. Both can be very entitled and rude and they rarely state their appreciation for helping them.
-Short-staffing is fairly common in most departments. I am convinced every organization is at least somewhat short-staffed, but it was an issue here.
-Opportunities for advancement are limited.
-Opportunities to transfer to other campuses for staff convenience are frequently denied with little to no explanation.

job_title: Human Resources Assistant in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: Reliable, Helpful, Encouraging, Trustworthy, Opportunity
cons: Federal Work Study ONLY - term employment upon graduation

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Grand Rapids, MI
pros:
Relatively relaxed environment but with major caveats
People are great, Teams are great, supervisors are great (So good, the cons can ALMOST be overlooked)
Great career opportunities
Lots of time off, but this will likely get cut based on trend
Values are good if they were followed by senior management
cons:
University hires 1 person to do the job of 3-5 people with the salary of <1
Work-life balance is not there due to above
Senior Management preaches values but doesn't follow any of them
Compensation doesn't come close to industry levels for anyone but senior management (which are WAY WAY overpaid)
Benefit costs go up 5% or more every year and we don't get pay increases so we've actually been getting pay cuts every year for at least 3 years
New this year, benefits get cut AND prices go up
Other low reviews refer to the previous president which were not inaccurate, right now, it's worse

review_title: Make sure you choose the right cup!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Grand Rapids, MI
pros:
Great people that work here. Everyone normally has positive disposition.
Benefits are great, even PT- employees get some kind of benefits.
Location is nice highway adjacent.
Tuition benefits
Parking is Free
cons:
No raise in 2 years executive leadership is awarded a raise before the grounds.
Lower level employees work seems to be undervalued.
You're asked to do more, but never compensated for it. Supervisors are normally quick to say thank you, but thank you's don't pay the bills.
Depending on your department you're notified about university changes at the last minute and sometimes not at all.
No real opportunity to advance. I was told there would be a chance to advance, but never happened. The 'favorites' seem to move a head easily.

review_title: Good People, Poor Management, and Pay
job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: My boss, Associate dept. chair and dept chair were great people.  Got to do a lot of neat things and earned a ton.
cons: Upper management was very stiff, especially in the college of Arts and Science.  Unwilling to try new teaching styles.  Asinine push for online learning, which in my opinion does not work well at the undergraduate level.  Great for Grad class but very poor for undergrad.  I had to leave because I was not making a livable wage.

job_title: Special Project Developer/Manager in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: Constructive classroom credit toward my degree program and an opportunity to better my alma mater.
cons: With much experience comes much expectation. The course credit was hard to earn as the work load was double or triple to that of classroom study. However, the impact the internship made was a great payoff for the university giving me a project I can be proud to hang my hat on.

job_title: Campus Assistant in Holland, MI
pros: Office has a very friendly and open environment. Everyone has been great to work with so far. I have been able to grow my network through various coworkers and improve my professional skills both on the computer and in person.
cons: There have not been many downfalls so far. I guess the only con that bothers me is the pay. It is a part time minimum wage position and I wish that with my previous experience that it could be paid more. This is outside of the employer's control though.

job_title: Professional Tutor in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: Remote tutoring is possible using Blackboard, even encouraged; tutoring from home was thus easy, so travel and travel-related expenses were not usually necessary.
cons: Remote access tech wasn't always 100% reliable. I'm sure it's improved by now. There are many campuses, so if you do find a need to be personally present for an appointment, be sure you understand with clarity which campus; Kalamazoo isn't the same as Battle Creek!

job_title: Company to Small in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: Rewarding work. Faster than public higher Ed. Great vacation policy and work life balance.
cons:
The president cares a lot about what people think of him and has little respect for those with expertise in their areas. 

Also, HR was terrible to work with on projects.

job_title: Instructor in Kalamazoo, MI
pros: Great company to work for. Open communication and clear expectations make it an enjoyable job.  The student basic requirements are clear and you tweek that to make the student learning experience the best that you can make it.
cons: The elctronic tool used for student assignments take a little while to learn.   However, the university does provide online and in person learning to master the tools.

job_title: Academic Department Head (Administrative) in Lansing, MI
pros: Great people to work with, many long time friends. Great vacation package if there was enough time to take any vacation days.
cons: Ruthless management, piling on more and more work. Often hidden agendas are suspected. Academics have too many jobs at too many campuses. One dept head might be responsible for 3-6 campuses, involving hundreds of miles of travel. When is he supposed to prep, teach?

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: The insurance and vacation time off.
cons: Low starting pay. No raises for 5 years, not even for cost of living. The university seems to be putting all its money toward its athletic program because they cannot sustain themselves. Management is out of touch and greedy. Its sad because this is a business school. You would think that they might do what they teach. If you don't blindly follow their demands you are labeled an outsider and your opinion doesn't count.

review_title: Leadership has no idea how overwhelmed Advisor's position
job_title: Advisor in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: Great team of employees. Everyone works together to get the job don.
cons: It is virtually impossible to work the combined role of Academic Advisor and Financial Aid Counselor that Advisors do. Especially when each Advisor has a team of over 300 students. Leadership has no clue of what goes on in the trenches.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Detroit, MI
pros: Great vacation time and insurance and wonderful co-workers
cons: Awful management, especially upper management, very out of touch of what goes on in the frontline. Only interested in keeping enrollment numbers up and shows no concern for the students or it's staff. This information pertains to several years ago when the previous President was in office. The current environment could be better or worse.

review_title: Great company, but no room for growth
job_title: Admissions in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: Flexibility, work/life balance, a chance to work with pretty cool people, and if you have the right boss, an opportunity for(individual) growth and learning in your department
cons: Some times there is favortism over education, experience and maturity. The problem with that is that you have unqualified people in powerful positions who make big decisions which effect the entire University.

job_title: Student Workshop in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: Student Workshop: It is a great way to make a little bit of cash on campus while taking classes. You get to meet a lot of people, and network. Great way to get involved on campus
cons: Student Workshop: The pay is pretty low, but what is there to expect. Certain student jobs only allow up to a certain amount of part time hours.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: The benefits are great, especially tuition remission for employees, their spouses, and dependent children.  Also very generous paid time off policy.
cons: The pay for lower level employees is not very good, while upper management receives an exceptionally high salary and lots of perks. It sometimes appears greed is the motivating factor for leadership decisions instead of what is best for the student population.

job_title: in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: The people you work with & PTO
cons: No room to advance, pay, upper management, never knowing when you will lose your job

job_title: Call Center Assistant (Work-study) in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: Cannot say enough good things about Davenport. Very flexible hours, no drug test, understanding staff, great atmosphere... the list goes on.  Also working at school is a great way to boost your career in the field you want to get into.
cons: I was work-study, so the pay wasn't the best, but that wasn't Davenport's fault.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: There are some great people working there for the good of the students' success in school and beyond.  Underlying entrepreneurial spirit can still be found after nearly 150 years.
cons: Atmosphere is ultra-conservative.  Diversity is not embraced.  There is a definite "old boys club" present.

review_title: i liked my location, upper management was unprofessional and unorganized
